Award.AwardTitle: Mathematical Questions Resulting from the Coupling of Gravity to Other Fields
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates three questions in general relativity: (i) The stability of solutions of electromagnetic and linearized gravitational waves in a Kerr (rotating) black hole background metric; i.e., solutions of the Cauchy problem for these partial differential equations with compactly supported initial data outside of the event horizon of the black hole. These stability results will add credibility to the use of the Kerr metric in detailed astrophysical models. (ii) Rigorous justification of the Penrose process for the extraction of energy from a rotating black hole. (iii) Incorporation of Guth's theory of inflation into the principal investigator's cosmological model.





Black holes have interested both physicists and mathematicians since Einstein proposed his theory of general relativity in 1915. They have been studied intensively, but many questions remain unanswered. This project explores three important questions. It investigates the stability of black holes under electromagnetic and gravitational perturbations. Such understanding is of great importance for predicting the nature of gravitational radiation originating in outer space. The stability problem will be considered in a manner parallel to the observations made by astronomers, leading to a better theoretical understanding of numerical modeling of solutions of Einstein's equations. The project also aims to put the question of extracting energy from a rotating black hole on a firm theoretical basis. The extraction of energy from a rotating black hole was proposed in 1968, but until recently the question was far too difficult to be studied. Finally, the project studies some questions in astrophysics dealing with cosmology and supernova explosions; these explosions of enormously dense massive stars undergoing gravitational collapse are responsible for seeding the universe with heavy elements, including carbon and iron.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Title: Mathematical Questions Resulting From the coupling of Gravity to other Fields

Intellectual Merit. This proposal is concerned with mathematical problems involving gravity which arise in astrophysics. The specific areas are: A) decay of solutions to the Cauchy problem for various important equations (Maxwell’s equations and gravitational waves), in a Kerr rotating black hole (KBH) geometry; B) Shock waves and expansion waves in General Relativity (GR); C) magnetic rotating Newtonian stars. Part A) continues the PI’s previous decay results for the Dirac and scalar wave equations to Maxwells equations in a KBH, and to the linearized Einstein equations around a KBH. Part B) deals with shock and expansion waves in GR and applying these wave solutions to problems in astrophysics; e.g. the Anomalous Acceleration of the Universe. Part C) arises from the PI’s recent existence and stability results for rotating Newtonian stars (e.g. our Sun), with an aim of extending these results to magnetic stars, in an attempt to better understand sunspots and solar flares.

In previous work, the PI and his collaborators proved the local L∞ decay of solutions to the Cauchy problem, with compactly supported initial data outside of the event horizon (the BH boundary) for both the Dirac equation and the scalar wave equation. We also made completely rigorous the celebrated 1969 Penrose proposal for energy extraction from a rotating BH. The PI considered the problem of decay of solutions of Maxwell’s equations as well as the decay of solutions to the linearized Einstein equations in a KBH background geometry. The latter result would prove the stability of gravitational waves as well the stability of the KBH under metric perturbations. The method of attacking these problems is via the Teukolsky equation, a 2nd-order PDE which separates into a radial and angular part, and first studying the angular equation, a second-order elliptic equation with complex coefficients.  We have analyzed the zeros of Airy functions and parabolic cylinder functions, and also obtained WKB error estimates for these functions.  These results play an important role in our program of proving the stability of the Kerr black hole under gravitational wave perturbations.

The PI and Blake Temple have recently found expansion wave solutions of Einstein’s equations which can be used to give an explanation of Dark Energy in the classical Einstein framework; i.e. without needing a cosmological constant. Our theory makes a prediction which in principle, can be verified. We considered these and related mathematical and physical questions, related to our program of developing a comprehensive theory of shock and rarefaction waves in GR.

The PI and his collaborator Tao Luo, proved the existence and global nonlinear stability of solutions of the compressible Euler-Poisson equations. These model Newtonian stars, and in particular, our Sun. We extended these results to MHD rotating stars, by incorporating a magnetic field into the equations, in order to better understand solar flares and sunspots which are thought to be due to strong magnetic fields in the interior of the star. The resulting equations are quite interesting from a mathematical viewpoint, and have not previously been studied rigorously.

Broader Impact. A main component of this endeavor is the integration of the research program with ongoing research and educational activities, the ultimate goal being to disseminate the beautiful and important ideas of general relativity (GR) to a broader audience of mathematicians. The PI organized a conference in May, 2011 on aspects of relativistic as well as non-relativistic fluids. This proposal  also provided problems for graduate students.
